items.title: 'We were in real danger': Australian who fled Iran recalls night crackdown arrived
items.description: On a visit to his hometown outside Tehran, this Iranian Australian joined the protests last Thursday night, then the regime's suppression methods turned from tear gas to live fire.

items.title: Venezuelan opposition leader 'presents' her Nobel Peace Prize to Trump
items.description: Maria Corina Machado says she presented Donald Trump with her Nobel Peace Prize medal during a meeting in Washington earlier today but did not say whether he accepted it.

items.title: PM gears up for fight with Liberal premiers on gun buybacks
items.description: A split is emerging at a state level over the government's plan to establish a national gun buyback scheme following the Bondi terror attack.

items.title: Future of Bondi terror attack bridge on hold after local opposition
items.description: Waverley Council held an extraordinary meeting last night, but the future of the footbridge used by the Bondi gunmen remains undecided.

items.title: Piecing together satellite images shows bushfire crisis unfolding
items.description: Hundreds of images captured by an orbiting weather satellite, and stitched together by the ABC, show the scale and destructive force of the Victorian bushfires.

items.title: Beach towns in shock after 'terrifying' historic deluge, flash flooding on Great Ocean Road
items.description: Camping spots near Lorne are surveying the wreckage today after record-breaking rains turned into "terrifying" floodwaters along Victoria's Great Ocean Road, sweeping cars into the ocean and inundating two holiday parks.

items.title: Households 'paid to switch off' as extreme weather stalks power grid
items.description: In a move labelled a sign of the times, energy firm AGL was last week offering customers money to cut use during a heatwave.

items.title: Zaida's son was snatched in the night and she's begging for his release
items.description: Venezuela's new leader says political prisoners are being freed, but hundreds remain jailed, with families clinging to hope that America's intervention and ongoing pressure will eventually secure their loved ones' release

items.title: Family questions hospital care after woman dies from bloodstream infection
items.description: Struggling to find answers about what happened in the week leading up to her death in hospital, Sue Smith's loved ones say they want hospitals to put more resources into investigating these types of incidents.

items.title: Millions of accounts culled days after social media ban started, data shows
items.description: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

items.title: Antidepressants failing many people, major study reveals
items.description: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for around 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.

items.title: Two blokes, whisky and lollies on a 'foolhardy' Bass Strait crossing
items.description: With whisky and lollies for sustenance and pigeons their only means of communication, Steve Harris and Doug Fleming crossed Bass Strait in a 4.5m dinghy in 1974.

items.title: What is in the government's new hate speech laws?
items.description: Parliament will return early next week to debate new hate speech laws. But what exactly does the legislation include?

items.title: White House shrugs off presence of European troops in Greenland
items.description: As European countries send small numbers of troops to Greenland, the White House says their presence will not affect US President Donald Trump's ambitions for the island.

items.title: Outrage after 'attack' on 100-year-old Anzac statue caught on CCTV
items.description: Residents of a north-west NSW town are angry and heartbroken after a statue with more than 100 years of history was unceremoniously shattered in the middle of the night.

items.title: Weekly news quiz: An early departure and an Aussie Golden Globe win
items.description: Test your knowledge of this week's news cycle here.

items.title: 'Babe, don't move': Woman wakes up to 2.5-metre python curled up on top of her
items.description: It's fair to say when a Brisbane resident woke up to discover a carpet python curled up on top of her she was rattled.

items.title: Are relentless computer updates driving you crazy? You're not alone
items.description: Have you turned on your work computer after a holiday, only to find so many updates and security enhancements that you may as well take a break before you start?

items.title: US lawsuit results in mystery cheque from Amazon in woman's mailbox
items.description: Australian woman Laura Wells was confused to find an "official-looking letter" from the US with a $51 reimbursement, but it turns out it was legitimate.

items.title: Red claw farmer expands to meet restaurant demand as industry production falls
items.description: Red claw is becoming more popular in restaurants across Australia, but the industry faces challenges with boosting production as more farmers retire.

items.title: Live: Aussie dollar nudges 67 US cents, Wall Street up on 'massive' AI chips deal
items.description: The Australian dollar jumps again on potentially more dovish policy from the US Federal Reserve, while Taiwan and the US have struck a major semiconductor deal. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

items.title: Twenty-four parkruns in 24 hours no sweat for WA runner
items.description: An Albany man runs roughly three marathons in laps of a hilly parkrun to raise funds for a charity that helped him through a tough time.

items.title: Days after family fled fires, flash flood forces them to evacuate again
items.description: A family holidaying at Wye River on the Great Ocean Road have been lucky to escape flash flooding less than a week after catastrophic fires drove them from their central Victorian home.

items.title: Ex-member says Shincheonji 'cult' spreading across the country
items.description: Documents leaked to the ABC reveal an "apocalyptic Christian cult" is targeting Ballarat, Bendigo, Geelong and Darwin.

items.title: Four more pipe bombs found in Canberra as probe continues
items.description: ACT police say they have found four more pipe bombs in the Belconnen area, after 11 explosive devices were discovered close to Lake Ginninderra over the previous two days.
